translated: The Collection of Threes🔽The First Section

analyzed: vuttam ha etam bhagavatā vuttam arahatā iti me suta
translated: This was said by the Blessed One, said by the Arahant, so I have heard:

original: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
analyzed: sukhā vedanā dukkhā vedanā adukkhamasukhā vedanā
translated: Pleasant feeling, painful feeling, neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.

original: imā kho, bhikkhave, tisso vedanā”ti.🔽Etamatthaṁ bhagavā avoca.
analyzed: imāḥ kho bhikkhave tissaḥ vedanā ti  etam attham bhagavān avoca
translated: These are the three feelings.”🔽The Blessed One said this.
And in connection with this, it was said:
“The monk who is concentrated, fully aware,
and the path that leads to their ending:
The monk who has seen with right discernment

original: nicchāto parinibbuto”ti.🔽Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
analyzed: nicchātaḥ parinibbuto ti  ayam pi atthaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā iti me sutam ti
translated: the ending of feelings is one who has crossed over clinging to the world.”
This, too, was the meaning of what was said by the Blessed One, so I have heard.🔽The third section on the three is finished.
